Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Select a suitable location that benefits from filter use, such as a landscape with contrasting elements. â€¢ Ensure you have a sturdy tripod to stabilize your camera for long exposures. â€¢ Familiarize yourself with your filter set and practice attaching them to your lens. â€¢ Set your camera to Aperture Priority or Shutter Priority mode. â€¢ Fix your ISO to 200 to maintain consistent exposure across different lighting conditions. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use ND filters to achieve longer exposure times without overexposing your image. â€¢ Incorporate GND filters to control the brightness difference between the sky and ground. â€¢ Adjust your aperture for depth of field while letting the camera manage shutter speed. â€¢ Utilize Polarizer filters to increase color saturation and contrast in your images. â€¢ Experiment with various strengths of ND filters to see their impact on exposure. Creative Focus â€¢ Capture flowing water in a river or waterfall using ND filters to create a silky effect. â€¢ Use GND filters during sunrise or sunset to prevent blown-out highlights. â€¢ Frame a scene where reflections in water can be enhanced using a Polarizer filter. â€¢ Experiment with landscape compositions that take advantage of enhanced colors from Polarizer filters. â€¢ Create abstract images by using long exposures with ND filters to blur moving subjects. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Use ND filters to photograph a waterfall in Aperture Priority mode at f/11 with ISO 200 fixed, allowing the camera to set the shutter speed for a smooth water effect. â€¢ Shoot a landscape during golden hour with a GND filter in Shutter Priority mode at 1/125s with ISO 200 fixed, letting the camera adjust aperture for balanced exposure. â€¢ Capture a vibrant sky with a Polarizer filter in Aperture Priority mode at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed, allowing the camera to set the shutter speed. â€¢ Photograph a busy street scene using ND filters to achieve motion blur while in Shutter Priority mode at 1/60s with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Use a GND filter to photograph a sunset over a lake in Aperture Priority mode at f/16 with ISO 200 fixed, letting your camera adjust the shutter speed to maintain depth of field. â€¢ Create a series of images that showcase the difference polarizing can make in colors and reflections, using Aperture Priority mode at f/5.6 with ISO 200 fixed. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Combine the use of both ND and GND filters in a single shot during the daytime, ensuring proper exposure using Aperture Priority mode. â€¢ Create a time-lapse video of a sunset using ND filters to control exposure, while switching between different filter strengths.
